title: Mechanics and Materials under Extremes
text:
I am developing a new program at the LMS to investigate the kinetics of phase transformations in a wide range of shape memory alloys (SMAs) under large multi-axial stress states and very short time scales. Development of dynamic, high-resolution experiments with multi-physical coupling is ongoing in the lab – with a lot of excitement! We eventually hope to discover the mechanisms behind such complex dynamic phenomena – one direction towards our broad goal of discovering micromechanics of defects under extreme conditions.
Collaborators: Prof. Suraj Ravindran (U. Minnesota)

title: Mechanics and Materials under Extremes
text:
With a density two-thirds that of aluminium, magnesium is currently sought after as the next-generation light-weight structural metal for a technology-driven, energy-sustainable future. Naturally, many applications of these materials require them to be resilient under impact loading conditions such as, in car crashes, military applications and space exploration. However, the mechanisms of plastic deformation and failure are non-intuitive at time scales on the order of micro-seconds and less. My doctoral research focused on understanding the fundamental mechanisms governing the strength of magnesium and it’s alloys.
Collaborators: Prof. K. T. Ramesh (JHU - PhD advisor), Dr. Meng Zhao (JHU), Dr. Debjoy Mallick (US Army Research Labs), Prof. Todd Hufnagel (JHU), Dr. Andrew Leong (JHU)

title: Mechanics and Materials under Extremes
text:
Architected materials are materials whose properties are designed at a fundamental unit cell length scale, and governed by the arrangement of these unit cells. We are interested in a specific class of such materials whose elastic wave dispersion characteristics may be designed through complex architectures at microscopic length scales. However, the ability to fabricate such materials, and measure their broadband acoustic dispersion characteristics are non-trivial, requiring significant development. We have broken new ground in the fabrication of dense architectures at the micrometer scales, and are now attempting to push the limits of understanding and controlling wave-guiding behavior through multi-scale design and characterization tools developed in house.
Collaborators: Prof. Charles Dorn (U. Washington at Seattle), Prof. Dennis M. Kochmann (ETH Zurich)

text: Congratulations to Tamar Tsikarishvili on completing her Bachelor Thesis defence! Tamar spent 10 weeks working on a new design for a dynamic shear experiment (a Torsional Kolsky bar). She performed admirably, and passed her defense with flying colors. Tamar is now exploring new waters literally! She is about to start a Nordic masters program in Maritime Engineering. While we are sad to see her go, we wish her great success in her future endeavors!

title: Tamar joins the team
text: Tamar Tsikarishvili has started her bachelor’s thesis with us. She will be developing designs for miniature dynamic experiments under multi-axial stresses. All the best, Tamar!

title: Our first grant award!
text: We have been awarded a four-year grant by the French National Research Agency (ANR) to study impact-induced phase transformations in magnetic shape memory alloys! Over the next four years we will be investigating the mechanisms behind such phase transformations at short time scales down to nanoseconds, using very exciting in-house experimental methods. I am absolutely delighted, more so because this is my first successful grant application. Looking forward to some very exciting science. I will be soon be hiring new doctoral/post-doctoral researchers. Stay tuned for updates…

title: Research
text:
We are excited by scientific problems that require us to push the limits of quantitative measurements across length and time scales. We develop specialized experiments for mechanics and multi-physics problems at short time scales. Examples involve miniature Kolsky bars (high strain rate impact), high-speed optical microscopy and interferometry, multi-scale electro-mechanical test beds, and pump-probe acoustic spectroscopy. Current and future directions will extend these capabilities to study transient material response under complex stress states with multi-physical coupling.

Ferroelectrics are a class of electro-active materials, ubiquitous across a wide range of technological applications e.g., energy harvesting, sensors & transducers, nano-electronics and active structures. At the core of these multi-functional applications is the coupling between electrical, mechanical and thermal fields. Microscopically, this manifests as the heterogeneous evolution of volume defects called “domains”, separated by planar defects called “domain walls”. Our efforts focus on understanding these dissipative kinetics, their effects on electro-mechanical switching and dynamic viscolelasticity in ferroelectric ceramics and crystals.
Collaborators: Prof. Dennis M. Kochmann (ETH), Prof. Morgan Trassin (ETH), Dr. Claire Griesbach (ETH)

title: Open positions
text:
Our team is growing! We have two open positions to be filled as soon as possible. Details below…

 




We are looking for a motivated and passionate post-doctoral scientist in the area of experimental mechanics and dynamic behavior of materials. You will lead an effort to study phase transformations under multi-axial stress states across a wide range of strain rates – spanning quasi-static to high-strain-rate dynamic loading conditions. This will involve the development of multi-axial quasi-static, and dynamic compression-tension-torsion experiments towards the discovery of phase transformation kinetics.
Does this excite you? Then please do apply! In case of questions, please feel free to contact me at vignesh.kannan@polytechnique.edu.
Complete application details can be found in the pdf attached ->

title: Mechanics and Materials under Extremes
text:
Mechanics and Materials under Extremes  We study materials under extreme conditions of stress, multi-physical fields, and at short time scales.





Experimental mechanics across extreme conditions  We develop specialized experiments motivated by the discovery of micromechanisms governing material response across length and time scales





Multi-scale mechanics of structural metals  How do metals behave under large strain rates and pressures? What are the fundamental mechanisms governing this response?





Multiphysical coupling in ferroelectric materials  We explore the origins of polarization switching and viscoelastic coupling in ferroelectric crystals at the meso length scales.





Microscale metamaterials for elastic wave guiding  Can we design, fabricate and characterize elastic wave guides with control over orders of magnitude in length scale?

title: Mechanics and Materials under Extremes
text:
Welcome! We are a growing team of undergraduate and graduate students, post-doctoral scientists and engineers, who study materials and structures under extreme conditions of stress, strain rate and multi-physical fields, at short time scales, within the Solid Mechanics Laboratory (LMS), Department of Mechanics at the Ecole Polytechnique in France.
Our primary tools of choice to study these problems are experimental. We use mechanical design, electronic and optical instrumentation to push the cutting edge of studying materials and structures down to time scales of nanoseconds, and length scales from the macroscopic down to micrometers.
Our experiments allow us to “see” the wondrous complexity of nature, but to comprehend this complexity we need models. We enjoy working with mathematical modelers to help understand complex phenomena, and hope to become amateur modelers some day! ​​​We hope you have fun reading about our work, and learn something in the process. If you would like to work with our team, know more about us, or teach us something more, please feel free to reach out. We are always looking for new perspectives to our way of thinking! Find out who we are!
To follow our most recent updates follow our News and Events page.

title: To new beginnings…
text:
I have moved to the Ecole Polytechnique to begin my career as an Assistant Professor of Mechanics. My research group will explore the areas of dynamic behavior of materials. Stay tuned for updates on the status of our research, and the evolution of the lab and research group. While my time in Switzerland was special and will be dearly missed, I will still be visiting the ETH to continue some of our work on elastic waves in microarchitected metamaterials.
